<@U0H6L5LQP|bit.llama> has joined the channel

no but need to share those think if you are getting stuck in find a *Dagger_*component  actually it will get a component at compile time.
I spent more than 2 hours to resolve. FYI only.
need to share what?

An important aspect of Dagger 2 is that the library generates code for classes annotated with the @Component interface. You can use a class prefixed with Dagger_ (i.e. Dagger_TwitterApiComponent.java) that will be responsible for instantiating an instance of our dependency graph and using it to perform the injection work for fields annotated with @Inject. See the setup guide and make sure you've included the android-apt plugin. This plugin will allow you to better understand the code generated by Dagger 2.

<@U0H71HGPQ|mersocarlin> has joined the channel
Could anybody help me with something using Retrofit?
I'm just trying to do a POST call to sign in, I'm not expecting an object back. How do I tell it, "Look man, I'm not expecting a list of damn objects. I just want to see the Json response"
<@U0H6L5LQP>: what version of Retrofit?
^ damn, he was first
use ResponseBody as the type parameter
Oh my god that's it
Jesus christ
May I ask why you just want the json?
Or do you want to the http code?
Cause if you want the JSON then why _not_ make it an object? If you want to get information out of it then it’s all done for you already.
some endpoints don't have response data but retrofit still requires you to declare a type i think
Is it proper to have a class to fit every single response json for an api?
Like should there be a "SignOnResponse" model object?
if you process the response -> usually yes
Well poo
Alright sounds good thanks guys
Pretty much saving me endless hours of torture.
Although, you know that one time that you have an API that can give back multiple types of responses on one endpoint. What do you do then? :smile:
(rewriting the API doesn’t count)
write a deserializer that detects the type of the response and delegates the deserialization to the appropriate class :wink:
And then you’ll still get the same POJO for each response?
So a JSON array will be of the same type as a JSON object.
See, in iOS I do that myself damien
And so some responses get converted manually to model objects by me
But some don't respond with data that represents an object, like Sign On
So at that point, you just return whatever values you need
what does the data represent?
So having a class for every single response to me is strange. But it sounds like the way to go with Java since everything needs to be in a class I suppose?
For example, it might return an auth token, which is just a string
You might want to store that in a Session singleton or something
Which has an auth token property
and else?
And a bunch of other stuff
That won't return with that token
So it doesn't translate from Json to Model smoothly
I mean the Session isn't even a model, it's a singleton

Also, the API I am working with will sometimes return only certain properties in certain ways, (due to silly developers on the backend), so at that point the JSON might appear SLIGHTLY different in certain calls.
